courseTitle: Determination of Ideal Gas Law Constant

pageData.titleName2: Determination of Ideal Gas Law Constant

pageData.text: Students will test the relationship between <button class=glossary-text>pressure</button> and the number of moles of gas as described by the <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas law</button>. Specifically, they will generate and collect oxygen gas from the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide in an enzymecatalyzed reaction. They will then determine the <button class=glossary-text>volume</button> and the number of moles of oxygen generated. From these quantities, they will predict the constant that governs the behavior of <button class=glossary-text>ideal gases</button>.

pageData.title: Overview Video: Determination of Ideal Gas Law Constant

text: Determine the <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas law</button> constant.
Use a <button class=glossary-text>catalyst</button> to initiate a gas-forming reaction.
Use the <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas</button> law to determine the number of moles of gas generated in a reaction.
List the kinetic theory assumptions about ideal gases.

pageData.text: Anytime we take a flight, we enter a closed space where oxygen is limited and become the beneficiaries of the <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas law</button>. Airplanes pump oxygen into the cabin to ensure enough oxygen is available for passengers. This oxygen comes from the engines which suck in outside air to generate thrust. The air is cooled, moisture is added, and then it is pumped into the cabin at a greater <button class=glossary-text>pressure</button> than the outside pressure experienced by the aircraft.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>How do airplane manufacturers know how much air is needed to keep passengers comfortable? The <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas</button> law is used in conjunction with the average pressure and percent of oxygen in the air to determine the amount of air needed in the cabin. Oftentimes, the application of the ideal gas law is monitored via an outflow valve. If the pressure in the cabin exceeds the setting on the outflow valve, the value opens, and the excess air is released to ensure a safe and comfortable cabin pressure as defined by the ideal gas law.

pageData.desc: The cabin of an airplane filled with seated passengers.
pageData.altText: The cabin of an airplane filled with seated passengers.

pageData.text: Gases are one of the three states of matter on earth and an integral part of the physical world. Understanding the behavior of gases is important to understanding the environment and the biological systems that it supports. An obvious example is the air that supplies oxygen, essential to all living things, and carbon dioxide, essential to plants and, therefore, our source of food. In this investigation, you will gain some insight into how gases, which are generally invisible, can be measured and how their behavior can be assessed.In this investigation, oxygen gas will be used. The atmosphere is about 20% oxygen, but this experiment requires pure oxygen gas. Pure oxygen in this investigation will be acquired from the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide to form oxygen gas, as shown below:2H2O2 → 2H2O + O2However, this reaction is relatively slow, and the rate of decomposition must be increased if the investigation is to be completed in a reasonable time. A can be introduced into a reaction to reduce the activation energy, effectively making it easier for a reaction to occur and to allow it to proceed at a reasonable rate. Importantly, a catalyst is not consumed and is not altered in the reaction, so it has no effect on the products or reactants and does not need to be included as either a product or reactant in the molecular equation. An enzyme from yeast, , will serve as the catalyst here.

Catalase is present in most organisms and enables their cells to decompose peroxides that are produced as part of normal cellular function. The presence of a catalyst is indicated in the molecular equation as follows:
2H2O2 catalase   2H2O + O2
As the gas is produced, it must be measured. The gas will be formed and collected in the apparatus shown in Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Photo of gas collection apparatus, with a graduated cylinder inverted into a beaker full of water. Plastic tubing goes from the mouth of the graduated cylinder and attaches to the top of a clear plastic bottle.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Photo of gas collection apparatus, with a graduated cylinder inverted into a beaker full of water. Plastic tubing goes from the mouth of the graduated cylinder and attaches to the top of a clear plastic bottle.

pageData.text: Hydrogen peroxide and yeast will be added to the dropper bottle, shown in <button className='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>. This combination will generate oxygen gas, which will flow through the tubing and into the inverted graduated cylinder. The graduated cylinder will initially be full of water, and as gas is generated, the water will be displaced. The <button class=glossary-text>volume</button> of gas in the graduated cylinder at any time will be equal to the volume of oxygen gas generated in the decomposition reaction. The apparatus is designed so that the <button class=glossary-text>pressure</button> in the reaction vessel will remain constant. This means that the pressure of the gas in the graduated cylinder will equal the pressure in the bottle, and the pressure in the apparatus will not change over the course of the experiment. The pressure in the entire reaction apparatus is designed to be equal to the ambient air pressure.

pageData.subTitle: Kinetic Theory of Gases
pageData.text: The <button class=glossary-text>kinetic theory of gases</button> explains the general behavior of gases by describing the movement of gas particles. Key assumptions allow the kinetic theory to predict the properties of an <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas</button>. Thus, a real gas may not always behave according to the assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases.

text: Gases consist of particles in constant, random motion that will move in a straight line until a collision occurs.
Particles are point masses with no volume. The particles are so small compared with the space between them, that we do not consider their size in ideal gases.
No molecular forces are at work. This means that there is no attraction or repulsion between the particles.
Gas pressure is due to the molecules colliding with the walls of the container. No energy is lost or gained from collisions.
The time during a collision is negligible compared with the time between collisions.

The <button class=glossary-text>temperature</button> is the average kinetic energy of all of the gas molecules. Individual gas molecules may move at different speeds, but the temperature and kinetic energy of the gas refer to the average of these speeds.
The kinetic energy of a gas particle is directly proportional to the temperature. An increase in temperature increases the speed at which the molecules move.
All gases at the same temperature have the same average kinetic energy.
Lighter gas molecules move faster than heavier molecules.

pageData.question: The kinetic theory of gases assumes which of the following?

options.text: Gas particles are in constant, random motion.
There is attraction and repulsion between gas particles.
Gas pressure is due to energy gained from collisions.
Lighter gas molecules move just as quickly as heavier molecules.
Changes in gas temperature do not impact the speed of gas particles.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The kinetic theory of gases assumes that gas particles are in constant, random motion and will move in a straight line until a collision occurs.

pageData.question: One assumption of the kinetic theory of gases is that gas pressure is due to the molecules colliding with the walls of the container and __________ .

options.text: no energy is lost or gained from collisions
colliding causes the temperature to increase
pressure (P) is the force a gas exerts on its surroundings
the gas molecules become attracted to the molecules of the container
the collisions result in curved paths of motion

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The kinetic theory of gases assumes no energy is lost or gained from collisions.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Modeling how gas particles interact requires some assumptions. For example, gases consist of particles in constant, random motion and will move in a straight line until a collision occurs. When gas particles collide with one another or the container there is no energy gained or lost. Particles are point masses with no volume. Gas pressure is due to the molecules colliding with the walls of the container. The particles are so small compared with the space between them, that we do not consider their size in ideal gases. These assumptions mean that kinetic theory very closely approximates the properties of a real gas, but the assumptions mean that the kinetic theory of gases models a so-called ideal gas and is not impacted by the assumptions below that would apply to a real gas.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Modeling how gas particles interact requires some assumptions. For example, gases consist of particles in constant, random motion and will move in a straight line until a collision occurs. When gas particles collide with one another or the container there is no energy gained or lost. Particles are point masses with no volume. Gas pressure is due to the molecules colliding with the walls of the container. The particles are so small compared with the space between them, that we do not consider their size in ideal gases. These assumptions mean that kinetic theory very closely approximates the properties of a real gas, but the assumptions mean that the kinetic theory of gases models a so-called ideal gas and is not impacted by the assumptions below that would apply to a real gas.

pageData.text: The behavior of gases is described by the <button class=glossary-text>Ideal Gas Law</button>, which incorporates several parameters that describe the gases under consideration and the interrelationships of these parameters. These parameters are <button class=glossary-text>pressure (P)</button>, <button class=glossary-text>volume (V)</button>, moles of gas (n), and its <button class=glossary-text>temperature (T)</button>. The Ideal Gas Law is:<span className=bodyParaLineBreak> PV = nRT <span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Each of these parameters is discussed below. When studying gases, it can be helpful to visualize the individual atoms or molecules that make up the gas, and this discussion employs this useful tactic.

Pressure is the force a gas exerts on its surroundings. This force is the result of the gas molecules colliding with a surface. Pressure can be expressed in pascals (Pa), millimeters mercury (mm Hg), or atmospheres. The SI unit for pressure is a pascal, equal to 1 newton per square meter; however, most people are more familiar with atmospheres (atm) as 1 atm is equivalent to atmospheric pressure at sea level.

Volume is the three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or milliliters (mL). The variable n is the number of moles of gas in the system and has a unit of mole (mol). Temperature is a measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K). A sample of gas with molecules that have a high average speed will have a higher temperature than a sample of gas with molecules with a lower average speed. Temperature measured in Celsius can be converted to Kelvin through the following equation:TKelvin = TCelsius + 273.15The constant is the gas law constant and has a value of 0.08206 (atm * L)/(mol * K).

pageData.question: The ideal gas law equation describes temperature (T) in units of Kelvin (K). How can temperature that is measured in Celsius (C) be converted to Kelvin?

options.text: add gas constant P to C
add gas constant R to C

pageData.question: The variable P represents what parameter in the ideal gas law equation?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pressure (P) is the force a gas exerts on its surroundings.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The behavior of gases is described by the ideal gas law, which incorporates several parameters and is described mathematically in Equation 1. Pressure (P) is the result of the gas molecules colliding with a surface. Pressure can be expressed in pascals (Pa), millimeters mercury (mm Hg), or atmospheres. Volume (V) is the three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or mL. The variable n is the number of moles of gas in the system and has a unit of mole (mol). Temperature (T) is a measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K). Temperature measured in Celsius can be converted to Kelvin through Equation 2. The constant R is the actual gas law constant and has a value of 0.08206 (atm•L)/(mol•K).

img.alt:
Equation 1: PV = nRT
Equation 2: T<sub>Kelvin</sub> = T<sub>Celsius</sub> + 273.15

Volume (V) is the three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or mL. The variable n is the number of moles of gas in the system and has a unit of mole (mol). Temperature (T) is a measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K). Temperature measured in Celsius can be converted to Kelvin through Equation 2. The constant R is the actual gas law constant and has a value of 0.08206 (atm•L)/(mol•K).

pageData.text: In this experiment, the relationship known as will be investigated. Avogadro’s Law states that the of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas. The and will be held constant in this investigation, allowing the experimental gas constant to be calculated if the moles of gas are graphed versus their volume:V = RT/PnThis can be compared to the equation of a line.y = mx + bIn this equation of a line, y is the volume (V), and x is the number of moles (n). The y-intercept (b) is equal to zero, since, if there are no moles of a gas, they would not occupy any volume. The slope of the line (m) is the term RT/P.m = RT/P

To solve for R, rearrange the equation for slope.R = mP/TThis experimental R value can then be compared to the actual R value through a percent error calculation.% error = (│actual – experimental│/actual) * 100This calculation shows how close the experimental value is to the known value of R.

Avogadro’s Law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas. The pressure and temperature will be held constant in this investigation, allowing the experimental gas constant R to be calculated if the moles of gas are graphed versus their volume.

Avogadro’s Law states that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas. The pressure and temperature will be held constant in this investigation, allowing the experimental gas constant R to be calculated if the moles of gas are graphed versus their volume.

pageData.altText: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In this activity you will perform two trials and measure the volume of gas produced from the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide by an enzyme found in yeast. You will then perform a series of calculations using the measured gas volume and additional measurements to determine the value of R, as well as the percent error of this experimental value compared to its actual value.

pageData.text: <span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Hydrogen peroxide causes skin irritation.
Hydrogen peroxide is corrosive and can cause serious eye damage.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation, and clean up the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

Wendy uses the apparatus shown here to collect the gas produced by the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide by the enzyme catalase. Which of the following describes how gas is collected in this apparatus?

imageData.altText: Figure 1: Photo of gas collection apparatus, with a graduated cylinder inverted into a beaker full of water. Plastic tubing goes from the mouth of the graduated cylinder and attaches to the top of a clear plastic bottle.

options.text: Water in the graduated cylinder is displaced by collected gas flowing through the tube.
The gas flows from the solution, through the tubing, and into the dropper bottle.
The gas bubbles into the graduated cylinder from the solution in the beaker.
The gas is captured in the dropper bottle, and excess gas escapes via the tubing.
Water in the beaker dissolves the gas flowing through the tube into the beaker.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is an assumption that applies to an ideal gas and not a real gas?

options.text: Gas particles move in constant, random motion.
Gas particles lose or gain energy as they collide with the container.
The size of an individual gas particle is significant compared to the gas’s total volume.
The kinetic energy of a gas particle is not proportional to the temperature.

Read procedure thoroughly.
Locate and clean work area.
Gather all needed materials.

In this activity, you will experimentally determine the gas law constant (<button class=glossary-text>R</button>) of the <button class=glossary-text>ideal gas law</button> equation. You will measure the <button class=glossary-text>volume</button> of gas produced from the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide by an enzyme found in yeast; you will conduct multiple trials of this reaction with varying amounts of hydrogen peroxide. Then, you will perform a series of calculations using the measured gas volume and additional measurements to determine the value of R, as well as the percent error of this experimental value compared to its actual value.
Determine the current air using the thermometer and record it in Data Table 1.
Fill the 50-mL graduated cylinder completely with water.
Fill the 250-mL beaker completely with water.
Attach the dropper top to one end of the clear tubing.
Insert the opposite end of the tubing into the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Note: The next step will cause the water in the beaker to overflow; have paper towels or a baking pan ready to collect any spills.
Place thumb over opening of the 50-mL graduated cylinder and invert into the beaker. See Figure 2 below for an illustration.

pageData.subTitle: Watch the video of how to assemble the collection apparatus.<span className='bodyParaLineBreak'>

pageData.desc: See how to assemble the collection apparatus.
Figure 2: Diagram showing the graduated cylinder being inverted into a beaker, with a gloved hand covering the opening to the graduated cylinder.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing the graduated cylinder being inverted into a beaker, with a gloved hand covering the opening to the graduated cylinder.

pageData.text: Record the initial of gas in the graduated cylinder in Data Table 1. If no gas is present, the volume will be 0.
Turn on the balance.
Place a weigh boat on the balance and tare it.
Weigh 0.1 gram of yeast into the weigh boat.
Pour the yeast into the empty 15-mL bottle.
Measure 1 mL of hydrogen peroxide in the 10-mL graduated cylinder. Record the exact volume in Data Table 1.
Prepare the end of the tubing with the dropper top.
Note: The top will need to be snapped in place immediately after the hydrogen peroxide is added.
Pour the hydrogen peroxide into the 15-mL bottle.
Snap the dropper top with tubing onto the bottle.
Allow the reaction to proceed until no additional gas has been generated for at least one minute. At this point, the reaction can be considered complete.
Record the final volume of gas in Data Table 1.
Calculate the change in volume in mL and record in Data Table 1.
Remove the top from the bottle, pour the contents down the sink, and rinse the bottle three times with water.
Repeat the activity using 1 mL hydrogen peroxide.
Repeat the activity varying the volume of hydrogen peroxide in step 12 as listed in the table below.

This activity will guide you through the creation of an XY scatter plot of moles of oxygen vs. of gas generated. This XY scatter plot can then be used to derive your calculated gas constant, , which can be compared with the actual R value to determine the percentage error. The goal is to have a low percentage error, meaning your calculated R value is close to the actual R value, which demonstrates the lab was performed as accurately as possible.

Calculate the molarity of (mol/L) of 3% hydrogen peroxide and record it in Data Table 2. The term “3% concentration” is a weight-to-weight measurement, which means that there are 3 g solute per 100 g solvent. The molar mass of hydrogen peroxide is 34.01 g/mol.
Calculate the moles of hydrogen peroxide present in each trial.
Calculate the moles of oxygen generated in each trial.
Convert the change in <button class=glossary-text>volume</button> from Activity 1 to liters.
Convert the air <button class=glossary-text>temperature</button> from Activity 1 from Celsius to Kelvin.
Using a computer graphing program, create an XY scatter plot of the moles of oxygen vs. volume of gas generated.
Create a best-fit line on your graph. Set the y-intercept equal to zero and display the equation on the graph.
Calculate the gas constant from the equation of your graph; assume that the = 1.00 atm.
Calculate the percentage error of the calculated R value with the actual value.

text: Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Rinse and dry the lab equipment and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Sanitize the workspace.

data.title: Avogadro’s Law
data.content: States that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to the number of moles of the gas

data.title: Catalase
data.content: Present in most organisms and enables their cells to decompose peroxides that are produced as part of normal cellular function

data.title: Catalyst
data.content: Speed up chemical reactions by lowering the activation energy required for the reaction

data.title: Ideal gas
data.content: Incorporates several parameters that describe the gases under consideration and the interrelationships of these parameters. These parameters are pressure (p), volume (V), moles of gas (n), and its temperature (T). The Ideal Gas Law is: PV = nRT

data.title: Ideal Gas Law
data.content: PV = nRT; shows the relationship of four variables for gases in one equation, where P represents pressure (in atmospheres [atm]), V represents volume (in liters), n represents the number of moles, R represents the gas law constant (0.0821 L-atm/ mole·K), and T represents temperature (in degrees Kelvin)

data.title: Kinetic theory of gases
data.content: Describes how the movement of gas particles is modeled under several assumptions

data.title: Pressure (P)
data.content: The force a gas exerts on its surroundings

data.title: R
data.content: The gas law constant with a value of 0.08206 (atm * L)/(mol * K)

data.title: Temperature (T)
data.content: A measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K)

data.title: Volume (V)
data.content: The three-dimensional space that a gas fills and is most commonly measured in liters (L) or mL
